questions.text: According to the Factories Act 1948, what is the maximum work hours per week including overtime work hours?
questions.solution:
Maximum work hours per week including overtime work hours is 60 hours.

Labour Day is celebrated every year across the world on the 1st of May to spread awareness about the rights and opportunities of every Labour which they should get for their welfare and betterment.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. 

Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush 2.0:

The government of India introduced IMI 2.0 to accelerate the vaccine drive and extend the coverage to children and pregnant women in identified districts and blocks from December 2019- March 2020.

Note: Currently, the government has completed Intensified Mission Indradhanush 5.0:

Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI 5.0), the flagship routine immunization campaign of the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare concluded all 3 rounds in October 2023. This is the first campaign to be conducted across all the districts in the country and includes children up to 5 years of age (Previous campaigns included children up to 2 years of age). It also had a special focus on improvement of Measles and Rubella vaccination coverage.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40 year old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40 year old man

questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants to a country is an example of prospective screening.

Screening of disease is done to detect unrecognized disease or defect, in apparently healthy individuals, by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures.

The difference between prospective and prescriptive screening is given below:

  Prospective screening Prescriptive screening
Definition People screened for others benefit People screened solely for their own benefit
Essential purpose Disease control Case detection
Request for screening Specific request from the authority Request from physician
Example
  • Immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis syphilis, yellow fever, etc;
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits, sex workers.
  • Screening of blood donors.
  • Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism.
  • Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
  • Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus.

Note: Most common neonatal disease to be screened for is neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Monetary benefit is measured in which of the following analyses?
questions.solution:
The monetary benefit is measured in a cost-benefit analysis.

In cost-benefit analysis, the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given programme is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programmes.

The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a particular programme, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

In cost-effective analysis, the benefit is expressed in terms of results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).

Input-output analysis: how much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time); and output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Network analysis: a network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

questions.text: A 24-month-old child weighing 11 kg was brought to the pediatric OPD. He had a respiratory rate of 38/min. On examination, chest indrawing was observed. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre  immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it appears that the child has pneumonia as diagnosed from the presence of chest indrawing. The next best step of management is to give oral amoxicillin for five days and send the child home.

This is based on the revised WHO classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia at health facilities. Pneumonia with general danger signs like inability to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargic or unconscious, stridor in a calm child or severe malnutrition needs antibiotics with urgent referral to higher centre.

The following image distinguishes the previous and revised classification and treatment of the childhood pneumonia.

World Pneumonia Day, marked every year on 12 November, to raise awareness about the toll of pneumonia – a leading killer of children around the world – and to advocate for global action to protect against, help prevent and effectively treat this deadly illness.

questions.text: An employee diagnosed with TB gets extended sickness benefit for:
questions.solution:
Extended sickness benefit is given for a period of 2 years.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: The standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: As per NCEP- ATP III, which of the following is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
As per NCEP- ATP III, high LDL is not included in the definition criteria of metabolic syndrome.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III). It includes:

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level: ≥100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the mean +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Mean +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Mean+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Mean+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: Calculating one variable using another variable is done by
questions.solution:
Calculating one variable using another variable is done using coefficient of regression.

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are:

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Air pollutants:

Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide Incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulfur dioxide

Common indoor air pollutants

From coal or fuel combustion

Include CO, PAHs, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, pesticides, and other biological pollutants


Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A person wants to study about the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, so he collects data about people diseased with lung cancer from government hospitals and the number of cigarette packets sold at the same time period. Which type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The type of study described is an ecological study as the unit of study is the population. The number of cigarette packets sold at the same time is data about the population.

Option A: The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is an individual.

Option C: There is no experiment done here. Hence, it is not experimental study.

Option D: Quasi-experiments are nonrandomized, pre-post intervention studies done when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct a randomized controlled trial. The unit of study is therefore patients or individuals and not population.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non exposed is given by which of the following variables?
questions.solution:
The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed is given by attributable risk.

Attributable risk is often expressed as a percentage.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A patient comes with a ​history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution:
A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: The variation in a data set is compared with that of another data set using:
questions.solution:
The variation in one data set is compared with that of another data set using the coefficient of variation (CV). It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

Related Pearl: Coefficient of Variation

  • The coefficient of variation (CV) is a statistical measure of the relative dispersion of data points in a data series around the mean.
  • It is done to measure of relative variability and it is also known as relative standard deviation (RSD).
  • It is expressed as a percentage of the mean and its formulas are given in the image below:

where σ and s = standard deviation; and μ and x = mean

  • In simpler terms, coefficient of variation (CV) = standard deviation x 100/mean.
  • CV usually gives an idea into the performance of a test or method. A CV of 5% gives the general idea that the method is good in its performance but a CV of more than 10% gives an idea that the method isn’t very good.

questions.text: Pandemic that occurred in 2009 was due to which influenza virus?
questions.solution:
Recent influenza pandemic occurred in 2009 due to the emergence of a novel H1N1 influenza A virus.

Past influenza pandemics:

  • 1968 pandemic due to H3N2 virus
  • 1957-58 pandemic due to H2N2 virus
  • 1918 pandemic due to H1N1 virus
